item.title: Trump’s tariffs take effect, potentially upending global trade and prices
item.description: The president has already announced frameworks of trade agreements with roughly a dozen of the country’s closest trading partners, including the United Kingdom, the European Union, Japan and South Korea. But goods from nations with which the U.S. does hundreds of billions of dollars of trade, such as India, Switzerland and South Africa, will see new taxes of up to 39 percent, with India’s rate set to jump to 50 percent in three weeks. Economists say the sweeping new taxes on imports will likely get passed on to U.S. consumers and businesses.

item.title: Trump warns companies they will pay double for computer chips unless they ‘build in the United States’
item.description: The president’s latest aggressive tariffs policy puts firms under pressure to pledge new investments in the U.S. and could make smartphones and other products more expensive. Apple won an exemption from the new levy after promising to spend an additional $100 billion on U.S. hiring and components.

item.title: Trump administration plans to scale back human rights criticism of El Salvador, Israel and Russia, leaked documents show
item.description: Documents reviewed by The Washington Post show the administration is planning to eliminate or downplay accounts of prisoner abuse, corruption, LGBTQ discrimination and other alleged abuses. The human rights reports were due to Congress earlier this year but have been delayed as the administration ordered extensive changes.

item.title: Research on reversing Alzheimer’s reveals lithium as a potential key
item.description: Scientists at Harvard Medical School have reported that they were able to reverse the disease in mice and restore brain function with small amounts of the compound lithium orotate, enough to mimic the metal’s natural level in the brain. The finding could lead to earlier detection of Alzheimer's, new treatments and a broader understanding of how the human brain ages.

item.title: Trump and Putin plan to meet on Ukraine as early as next week, with a possible Zelensky meeting to follow
item.description: “The Russians expressed their desire to meet with President Trump, and the President is open to meeting with both President Putin and President Zelensky,” White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement. A meeting could come as soon as next week, according to an administration official.

item.title: Tulsi Gabbard overrode CIA officials’ concerns to release classified report on 2016 Russian election meddling
item.description: CIA officials worried that the release of the House report could reveal top-secret spying techniques and sources, but Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard authorized a lightly redacted version in July, with President Donald Trump’s blessing.

item.title: Five soldiers were shot at Fort Stewart in Georgia, Army says. A suspect is in custody.
item.description: It was not immediately clear whether there were any fatalities. The five victims were taken to a hospital for treatment, officials said. The base was put on lockdown as law enforcement responded to the incident.

item.title: One gene reveals clues to why humans thrived and Neanderthals didn’t
item.description: An international team of researchers scrutinized a version of a gene, ubiquitous in humans today, that is not present in Neanderthals or Denisovans — the hominins that lived alongside our ancestors. Their findings suggest tiny changes in brain chemistry could trigger behavioral change that sets us apart from Neanderthals.

item.title: In beloved national parks, deep concern among Americans of all political persuasions
item.description: To see how the parks are faring amid the turmoil of the federal government’s downsizing, Washington Post reporters visited four locations just before peak summer season. We found that changes so far were subtle, though staff members cautioned that issues might emerge in coming months. We also found profound affection for America’s “crown jewels” — as the national parks have historically been described — strong support for their protection, and vivid concern over what budget and staffing cuts will mean in the years to come.

item.title: Smithsonian says it will restore information about Trump’s two impeachments to museum exhibit in coming weeks
item.description: The announcement came two days after the Smithsonian said it had removed Donald Trump’s name from the exhibits about presidential impeachments at the National Museum of American History. The Washington Post reported on Thursday that in July the museum removed a temporary placard describing Trump's impeachments and reverted the exhibit to how it looked in 2008.
